File.Title: The Organization of the Efferent Projections From the Pontine Parabrachial Area to the Amygdaloid Complex: A Phaseolus vulgaris Leucoagglutinin (PHA-L) Study in the Rat
File.Authors: JEAN-FRANCOIS BERNARD, MARIE ALDEN, AND JEAN-MARIE BESSON

Abstract.S: The organization of the efferent projections from the pontine parabrachial (pPB) area to the amygdala has been studied in the rat by using microinjections of Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHA-L), a sensitive and selective anterograde axonal marker, into restricted subregions of the pPB area.

The results confirmed that the pPB area primarily projected onto the ipsilateral nucleus centralis of the amygdala (Ce), and to a lesser extent onto the ipsilateral posterior basolateral (BLP), anterior basomedial (BMA), and amygdaloid cortical (ACo) nuclei of the amygdala.

Substantial projections were also found in the substantia innominata dorsaliventral portion of the globus pallidus (SIdlGPv), substriatal (SStr), and fondus striatal (FStr) regions which continue the amygdala rostrally.

The results demonstrated that the projections of the pPB area onto the Ce were topically organized: 1) The region of the pPB area mainly including the medial subnucleus (pPBm), the waist area (pPBwa), and a thin rostral lamina of the ventral lateral subnucleus (pPBvl) projects primarily to the medial portion of the Ce (CeM).

Dense projections were also found in the BLP, BMA, and ACo nuclei of the amygdala, and in the SIdlGPv, SStr, and FStr rostral areas. 2) The region of the pPB mainly including the rostral portion of the central lateral subnucleus (pPBcl) and the outer-rostra1 portion of the external lateral subnucleus (pPBel) projects primarily to the lateral portion of the Ce (CeL). 3) The region of the pPB mainly including the dorsolateral subnucleus (pPBdl), the remaining pPBel, and the external medial (pPBem) suhnuclei projects primarily to the lateral capsular portion of the Ce (CeLC) and bilaterally to its rostral portion.
Dense projections were also found in the regions which extend the CeLC rostrally and in the SIdlGPv, SStr, and FStr rostral areas.
The possible role of each of the three parabrachio-amygdaloid pathways described is discussed.

It was suggested that the pPB-CeM pathway is mainly implicated in gustatory processes; the pPB-CeL pathway is mainly implicated in visceral and chemosensitive processes; and the pPB-CeLC pathway is mainly implicated in respiratory, cardiovascular, and nociceptive processes. c 1993 Wiley-Liss, Inc.

Introduction.S: The pontine parabrachial (pPB) area is a group of cells that surrounds the brachium conjunctivum (bc) in the dorsolateral pons up to the mesencephalon where it continues into the mesencephalic parabrachial area (mPB).

Thc pPB area was considered for a long time to be a gustatory relay (Herrick, '05; Barnard, '36; Norgren and Leonard, '71, '73; Norgren and Pfaffmann, '75; Norgren, '78; Ogawa et al., '87; see review in Travers et al., '87).

More recently it has also been implicated in an increasing number of autonomic regulations (Bertrand and Hugelin, '71; Mraovitch et al., '82; Cechetto and Calaresu, '83; Darlington and Ward, '85a,h; Lumh and Morrison, '87; Ohman and Johnson, '89; see also Herbert et al., '90).
Increasing evidence has shown that this area is also implicated in nociceptive processes.

Indeed, several authors (Cechetto et al., '85; Hylden et al., '85, '86b; Panneton and Burton, '85; Light et al., '87; Blomqvist et al., '89; Hayashi and Tabata, '89) have found that a portion of this area receives a large input from neurons located in lamina I of the spinal and medullary dorsal horns, which are driven by noxious stimuli.

Bernard and Besson ('88, '90a) have recently demonstrated that a high proportion of neurons located in the external pPB (pPBe) area [i.e., external lateral (pPBel) and external medial (pPBem) subnuclei], and antidromically driven from the nucleus centralis of the amygdala (Ce), respond specifically to noxious stimuli.
Further investigations at the Ce level (Bernard et al., '90, '92) showed that numerous neurons responded to noxious stimuli.
However, these nociceptive neurons were not homogeneously distributed in and around the Ce.
We hypothetized that such a distribution could be linked to the pattern of projection from the pPB area to the Ce.

However, despite numerous anatomical studies demonstrating the efferent projection from the pPB area to the Ce, in the rat (Norgren, '76; Ottersen and Ben-Ari, '78; Saper and Loewy, '80; Ottersen, '81; Voshart and van der Kooy, '81; Fulwiler and Saper, '84; Bernard et al., '89; Moga et al., '901, the cat (Nomura et al., '79; Russchen, '82; Ma et al., '89; Berkley and Scofield, '901, the hamster (Halsell, '921, the rabbit (Kapp et al., '891, the monkey (Mehler, '80), the detailed location of terminal fibres in the Ce subdivisions from the pPB subnuclei is so far to a large extent unknown.
In the present study, we therefore used the very sensitive and selective anterograde axonal marker, Phaseolus r?
ulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHA-L) (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84), injected into very restricted sites, in order to determine projections from subregions of the pPB onto the amygdaloid subnuclei.
Preliminary reports of some of this work have been published (Bernard and Besson, '90b; Bernard et al., '91).

Methods.S: METHODS
Surgical procedures were performed on 68 male SpragueDawley albino rats, weighing 275-300 g, under chloral hydrate anaesthesia (400 mg/kg, i.p.1.
The animals were mounted in a stereotaxic frame.
The head was fixed in a dorsiflexed position (incisor bar elevated 10 mm above the standard position) (Paxinos and Watson, '86).
A craniotomy was performed on the right side, at the frontoparietalis suture level and the dura was opened.

Iontophoretic application of a 10% solution of PHA-L (Vector Labs, Burlingame, CA) were made through glass micropipettes (25-40 pm diameter tips) inserted in the brain on the right side 1.0-3.0 mm rostral to the Lambda, as defined in the stereotaxic atlas of Paxinos and Watson ('86), and 1.2-2.8 mm lateral to the midline.
The depth was between 6,500 and 8,000 pm.
A positive 15 seconds on-15 seconds off pulsed DC current (3-6 FA) was used for a time period between 15 and 30 minutes.

Following a postoperative survival time of 2-3 weeks, the animals were re-anaesthetized and perfused with i) a warm (37Â°C) heparinized phosphate-buffered saline solution (= 3 minutes duration) followed by ii) a cold (3 10Â°C) phosphate buffer solution (0.1 M; pH 7.4) containing 4% paraformaldehyde, 0.1% glutaraldehyde, and 0.05% picric acid (0.8 liter; 'LO minutes duration), followed by iii) a 20% sucrose, phosphate-buffered solution ( 10 minutes duration).
The brain and the spinal cord were removed and soaked in this last solution.
One day later, 50 pm thick coronal sections were cut on a freezing microtome.
The sections were rinsed several times with a phosphate buffer solution (PBS) (0.15 M; pH 7.4).
These sections were divided into three groups and processed for PHA-L immunohistochemistry.
All of the groups of sections were incubated for 2-4 hours in PBS containing 0.4% Triton X-100 and 2% normal rabbit serum (NRS).
They were then incubated overnight in the primary anti serum. i.e., l/l,OOO-l/2,000 goat anti PHA-L (Vector Labs, Burlingame, CAI, in PBS containing 0.4% Triton X-100,2% NRS.

After rinsing for 20 minutes with PBS the sections were incubated for 1 hour in the secondary anti serum, i.e., 11200 anti-goat-IgG (Vector Labs, Burlingame, CAI in PBS containing 0.4% Triton X-100,2% NRS.
After rinsing again for 20 minutes with PBS, the sections were placed in the avidin-biotin-HRP complex solution (kit vector, recommended dilution x 1.5, in PBS) for 1 hour.

The sections were then once more rinsed for 10 minutes with PBS, followed by two different types of peroxidase histochemical revelations: 1) The sections processed only with 3,3'-diaminobenzidine (DAB, Sigma Chemical Co., St.
Louis, MO) were once more rinsed for 10 minutes with PBS and then they were incubated in PBS containing 0.05% DAB for 2 minutes.
Next, increasing doses of H202 were added every 5 minutes to the latter DAB solution in order to obtain the following Hz02 concentrations (0.003%, 0.015%, 0.045%, 0.075%, and 0.225%).
The reaction was stopped by a 10 minutes rinse in PBS.

2) The two series of sections where the processes were enhanced with nickel were now rinsed 10 minutes with Tris buffer (0.15 M; pH 7.41, followed by an incubation in a Tris buffer solution containing 0.05% DAB and 0.2% amonium nickel sulfate (Sigma Chemical Co., St.
Louis, MO) for 2 minutes.
Then, increasing doses of H20z were added every 5 minutes to the latter DAB solution in order to obtain the following Ha02 concentrations (O.OOl%, 0.005%, 0.015%, 0.02596, and 0.075%).
The reaction was stopped by a 10 minutes rinse in Tris buffer.
Finally, one of these two series was counterstained with neutral red.
The injection sites, labelled fibres, and terminals were observed under brightand darkfield illumination.
Delineation of the parabrachial area and the amygdala was based upon observation of two Nissl-stained (one with cresylviolet and the other with thionin) series (50 pm thick) not processed for PHA-L.
Two series of drawings (50 pm apart between adjacent drawings) of the parabrachial area and the amygdala were made with the camera lucida drawing tube.
These drawings were used to make a standard drawing (150 pm apart) of both the parabrachial area and the amygdala.

The delineation and nomenclature of this region was adopted from relevant literature (McDonald, '82; Fulwiler and Saper, '84; Cassel et al., '86; Paxinos and Watson, '86) with some minor modifications (see, in Discussion, the section devoted to the nomenclature).
Each injection site was analyzed from a series of camera lucida drawings (150 pm apart) of the coronal section through the site (processed only with DAB).

The coronal plane where the inferior colliculus merges with the pons was used as reference plane (Pr) (this plane corresponds to the interaural -0.30 mm plane in the atlas of Paxinos and Watson '86) and the distance was measured (50 pm units) between each coronal plane drawing and the Pr (the distance was negative or positive for drawings caudal or rostra1 to the Pr, respectively); special attention was devoted, at the cutting stage, to obtain a well-standardized coronal plane of section.

For illustrative purposes the injection sites (delineated from the labelled cells) were grouped on standard drawings of two representative coronal sections (300 pm apart) of the parabrachial area (see Fig. 4).

In selected cases (see Figs. 5A, 7A, 9A-13A) camera lucida drawings of one or two coronal sections (300 pm apart), demonstrating the injection site, were presented according to the size of the injection site.
Each amygdaloid area (with special attention to the Ce) was analyzed from a series of camera lucida drawings (300 pm apart) of the labelled area (revealed with the enhanced nickel reaction).

In current cases the delineation of the subnuclei of the amygdala, the white matter fasciculi and the blood vessels were precisely drawn (with the use of adjacent counterstained sections), before the labelling was applied (with the camera lucida drawing tube) by different intensities of grey according to the density of labelled terminals in different areas.

In more interesting cases individual fibres were drawn, but even in those cases, taking into account the very high density of very thin terminal fibres, we drew only a representative subgroup of fibres in order to give a better representation of the density of terminals in different areas.

Consequently, it must be emphasized that, despite the undisputable labelling observed in direct microscopic observations, a clear and reliable representation of the labelled area was difficult to obtain.

The photomicrographs (see Figs. 2, 3) illustrated this well: the more densely labelled areas appeared as black areas, whereas in the areas with a lower density of labelling the very thin (diameter < 1 pmj black labelled terminals were weakly visible.

With a higher magnification it was possible to improve the quality of fibre details but further information, especially on the extent and the comparative density of labelled terminals, could no longer be illustrated.

Results.S: RESULTS
The present results are based on 63 experiments in which the PHA-L injection sites were located in (n = 43) or around (control experiments; n = 20) the pontine parabrachial area (pPB).
In each of the 63 selected experiments the injection sites (size between 150 and 800 pm) contained densely labelled cells around a dense stained core (Fig, 1).
Away from the injection site at least one cluster of densely labelled terminals was observed (Figs. 2, 3).

The injection sites presented here covered most, if not all, of the subnuclei of the pPB area (Fig. 4) [the nomenclature was for the main part adopted from Fulwiler and Saper ('841, see also Fig. 14Al.

TTE.S: It was primarily observed that 1) most of the injections of PHA-L in the pPB give rise to a high or very high density of labelled terminals in subdivisions of the ipsilateral nucleus centralis of the amygdala (Ce).
In these regions the labelling appeared as a dense network of very thin, black stained fibres, with numerous ramifications and varicosities.
In the more dense areas the labelling appeared as a cluster of entangled fibres in which it was difficult to identify individual fibres (see Figs. 2, 3).
A higher magnification photomicrograph of a Ce region containing a high density of labelled terminal fibres is illustrated in Figure 3C3.
Medium and low density were comparatively illustrated in Figure 3C2 and C1, respectively.

2) in the Ce, the dense network of labelled terminals was often restricted to one of its three subdivisions: the medial portion (CeM) (Figs. 2A, 3A), the lateral portion (CeL) (Fig. 2B), and the lateral capsular portion (CeLC) (Figs. 2C, 3B) [the nomenclature was for the main part adopted from McDonald ('82) and Cassel et al. ('861, see also Fig. 14BI.

Results.S: The location of the labelled area in one of these Ce subdivisions was closely linked to the location of the injection site in the pPB.

In Figure 4 the more representative injection sites (27 among the 43 located into the pPB) were grouped according to the subdivision of the Ce in which the dense network of labelled terminals was observed.
Thus, the injection sites shown in Figure 4A projected mainly or exclusively to the CeM.
Figure 4B shows the injection sites which projected both to the CeM and the CeL.
The groups in Figure 4C,D illustrate the sites projecting to the CeL and the CeLC, respectively.
The results were presented according to the grouping of sites made in Figure 4.
Experiments exhibiting a high density of labelling mainly in the CeM
These experiments exhibited a quite similar pattern of labelling in the Ce: the labelled terminals were located mainly or exclusively in the CeM subdivision.
The injection sites of ten representative experiments are shown in Figure 4A.
These injections covered the whole medial subnucleus of the pPB area (pPBm), the waist area (pPBwa), and the more medial portion of the pPBem.

Among these injection sites, three subgroups could be distinguished according to the location of the area with the densest labelling in the CeM: the central subgroup included sites No. 13 and 37, which primarily projected to the centre of the CeM; the ventral peripheral subgroup included sites No. 11, 21, and 23, which primarily projected to the medial periphery of the CeM; and the dorsal peripheral subgroup included sites No. 16,32,36, and 40, which primarily projected to the lateral periphery of the CeM, near the CeL.
The central subgroup.
The corresponding injection sites (No. 13 and 37) were located in the central portion of the pPBm (Fig. 4A).
The main common feature of this group was the location of densest labelling in the centre of the CeM.
The experiment No. 13 in which the site was exclusively located inside the pPBm was chosen as the representative case and described in detail.
Experiment No. 37 was briefly described in comparison to case No. 13.

TTE.S: Experiment No. 13 is illustrated in Figures 5 and 6.
The injection site had a small dense core in the caudal portion of the pPBm (Figs. lA, 5Al).

The numerous and densely labelled cells were almost exclusively located in the pPBm where they covered a large portion [Fig. 5A1,2; 200-900 km caudal to the coronal plane of reference (Prj where the inferior colliculus merges with the pons].
Only the more medial and the more rostral portion of the pPBm did not contain labelled cells.
The area of termination, in the amygdaloid complex, was primarily located in the ipsilateral CeM (Figs. 5B, 6).
The anterograde labelling occupied almost exactly the whole of the CeM (Figs. 5Bl-B2, 6B3-B5) with a very high density of labelled terminals in its centre (Figs. 5B2, 6B3-B4).
A thin lamina with a high density of fibre labelling surrounds the CeL.
This region which does not correspond neither to the CeL nor to the CeLC was here considered as an extension of the CeM.
This intense labelling contrasted strongly to the almost complete absence of labelling in the other subregions of the Ce: the CeL and the CeLC.

The few labelled fibres encountered in the CeL (Fig. 5B1,BZ) and in the CeLC (Fig. 6B3-B5) looked like fibres of passage (few ramifications, absence of varicosities, thicker than the other terminals, and all extended in the same direction).

The labelling in the Ce was continuous (Fig. 6B5,B6) with labelling i) in the transition area between the dorsal portion of the substantia innominata and the ventral portion of the globus pallidus (SId/GPv), and ii) in the substriatal area (SStr).

At this level, a lower density of labelling was also found i) in the anterior amygdaloid area, ii) in the fondus striatum (FStr), and iii) in the transition area between the globus pallidus and the caudate putamen (GPICPu).

In the amygdala, outside the Ce, a medium density of labelling was found mainly in the basomedial anterior nucleus (BMA), the adjacent portion of the anterior cortical amygdaloid nucleus (ACo) (Figs. 5B2, 6B3-B4) and the basolateral posterior nucleus (BLP).
In the contralateral amygdala the location of the labelled terminals was symmetrical to that on the ipsilateral side, but the density of labelling was considerably lower.
The labelling was observed in the SidiGPv and the SStr with a mehum to low density and in the CeM with only a low density.

Experiment No. 37, which had an injection site located in the medial portion of the pPBm (Fig. 4421, had an area of termination in the amygdaloid complex quite similar to that in case No. 13 but with an even greater density of labelling.
Specifically, as in case No. 13, the fibre labelling occupied the whole CeM, with the highest density of labelled terminal being in the centre of this area (Figs. 2A, 3A).
Labelled terminals were completely absent in the CeLC but, in slight contrast to case No. 13, a few fibres were labelled in the CeL (Fig. 2A).
The ventral periphera1 subgroup.
The corresponding injection sites (No. 11, 21, and 23) were located in the lateral and ventral portion of the pPBm (Fig. 4A).

The terminal labellingwas found, as in case No. 13, primarily in the CeM, but the most densely labelled area was located in the medial portion of the CeM: it surrounded the commissural stria terminalis (cst) in the caudal portion of the CeM and was located over the cst in the rostral CeM.
In the other regions of the amygdala the distribution of labelling was basically the same as that in the central subgroup.
The dorsal peripheral subgroup.
The corresponding injection sites were located in the more medial portions of the pPBm (site No. 40) and in the pPBwa (site No. 16, 32, and 36) (Fig. 4A).

The main area of termination was, as in experiment No. 13, primarily located in the CeM but, in all experiments in this group, the most densely labelled area was seen in the lateral portion of the CeM on the border of the CeL.
In the other regions of the amygdala the distribution of labelling was also basically the same that in the central subgroup.

Results.S: Thus, when considering the sites from the ventrolateral pPBm towards the dorsomedial pPBm and the pPBwa, the location of the densest projection area changed from the more medial to the more lateral portion of the CeM adjacent to the CeL.
Experiments exhibiting a high density of labelling both in the CeM and in the CeL
In these cases, the area containing a high density of labelled terminals included not only the CeM but also a portion of the CeL.
The injection sites of five representative experiments were presented in Figure 4B.
All these large injection sites overlapped the brachium conjunctivum and covered a portion of the lateral pPB area (pPB1); some of them also covered a large portion of the pPBm area (Fig. 4B).

These experiments made it possible to observe the transition area or the boundary between the region of pPB which projected primarily to the CeM (see section 1) and the region of pPB which primarily projected to the CeL (see section 3).
Chosen among these experiments, the case No. 34 (Fig. 4B) has been described in detail.
The other cases (No. 39,56,2, and 64) are described in comparison to the former.

TTE.S: Experiment No. 34 is illustrated in Figures 7 and 8.
The injection site had a dense core in the pPBwa surrounded by numerous and densely labelled cells over a relatively large area (Fig. 7A1,A2; 700-100 pm caudal to the Pr).

This injection covered a large portion of the pPBwa, the portion adjacent to the pPBm and in addition to the injections of section 1 (Fig. 4A1, a relatively large and rostral portion of the ventral lateral pPB subnucleus (pPBvl).
The area of termination, in the amygdaloid complex, was primarily located in an ipsilateral area overlapping both the CeM and the CeL (Figs. 7B, 8).
The density of terminal labelling was very high in this area, especially at the junction between the CeM and the CeL (Figs. 7BI-B2, 8B3).
The labelled area occupied only the lateral half of the CeM and a small adjacent portion of the CeL.

A thin lamina with a high density of fibre labelling surrounded the laterocaudal portion of the CeL, but the contrast to the centre of CeL was not as marked as in case No. 13 since the adjacent lateral portion of CeL contained a medium density of labelled terminals.
The intense labelling in the CeM and the CeL contrasted with the complete absence of labelling in the CeLC.
The labelled fibres encountered in the ventral portion of the CeLC (Fig. 7Bl,B2) appeared clearly as fibres of passage (probably from the Ce towards the BMA).
The labelling in the Ce was continued rostrally (Fig. 8B5,B6) with a distribution similar to that observed in case No. 13.
In the amygdala, outside the Ce, a high to medium density of labelling was found mainly in the BMA, the ACo (Figs. 7B2, 8B3,B4) and the basolateral posterior nucleus (BLP; Fig. 7BO).
A low density of labelled terminals was also observed in the medial anterior amygdaloid nucleus (MeA) and the piriform cortex (Pir).
In the contralateral amygdala the location of the labelled terminals, as in case No. 13, was symmetrical to that on the ipsilateral side, but the density of labelling was considerably lower.
Experiment No. 39 had a large injection site with an extent basically similar to the injection No. 34 but in a more lateral location (Fig. 4B).
The projection to the amygdala was similar to that in case No. 34, although even more dense.

Results.S: Thus, most of the areas of termination (primarily the CeM, and the BMA, ACo, and BLP) observed in experiments No. 34 and 39 were similar to those described in the previous section.
The only striking difference from experiments in that section was the intense labelling in the CeL on the border of the CeM.

A comparison of injection sites No. 34 and 39 (Fig. 4B) to the injections in the previous section (Fig. 4A) suggested that the more dorsal extension of the injections No. 34 and 39 in the pPBvl could be responsible for the labelling observed in the CeL.

TTE.S: Experiment No. 56 was for the most part similar to case No. 39.

The only noticeable difference was a larger extent of the injection site into the dorsal lateral pPR subnucleus (pPBdl) (Fig. 4B) which appeared to be associated to an additional labelling in a small portion of the rostral CeLC, adjacent to the CeL.
Experiments No. 2 and 64 included the most lateral injection sites of this serie (Fig. 4B).
The main labelling in the Ce had a distribution similar to those of previous cases of this serie at the junction between the CeM and the CeL, but with a predominance in this latter subdivision.
In addition in case No. 2 a small but significant labelling was observed in the caudal portion of the CeLC.

Results.S: Thus, experiments in this series, as compared to the previous one, primarily suggested that the pPRvl contained neurons which send axonal projections to the CeL.
To a lesser extent it also suggests (cases No. 2 and 56) that caudally, the pPBvl and the pPBel contain neurons projecting to the CeLC.
These suggestions are sustained and completed by experiments in the following section (sites projecting to the CeL) and subsequent section (sites projecting to the CeLC).
Experiments exhibiting a high density of labelling in the CeL
Among experiments with injection sites located in the pPB, three of them exhibited, in the Ce, an area of intensely labelled terminals located mainly in the CeL subdivision.
These injection sites (Fig. 4C) mainly covered the central lateral subnucleus of the pPB area (pPBcl; experiments No. 27 and 65) and the outer portion of the pPBel (experiment No. 60).

TTE.S: Experiment No. 27 is illustrated in Figure 9.

The injection site had a small dense core in the rostral portion of the pPBcl surrounded by numerous densely labelled cells which covered almost all the pPBcl and an adjacent portion of the pPBvl (Fig. 9A; 0-400 p,m caudal to the Pr).
The area of termination, in the amygdaloid complex, was primarily located in the ipsilateral CeL (Fig. 9B).
As shown in Figure 9Bl-B5 a high density of labelled terminals occupied almost the whole CeL.
This intense labelling strongly contrasted with the weak labelling in the other subregions of the Ce: the CeM and the CeLC.
Only a small cluster of labelled terminal fibres was observed below the CeL, on the border between the CeM and the CeLC (Fig. 9Bl-B3).
The few other labelled fibres encountered in the CeM and the CeLC (Fig. 9Bl-B5) looked like fibres of passage.
Only a few labelled terminals in the SIdiGYv and the SStr (Fig. 9B6) were labelled rostral to the Ce.
In the amygdala, outside the Ce, a few labelled terminals were observed in the medial nucleus of the arnygdala (Me).
In the contralateral amygdala only a few labelled terminals were observed in the CeL.

Results.S: Experiment No. 65 had an injection site centred in the pPBcl as did the injection No. 27 (Fig. 4C).
The rostrocaudal extent of this injection site was larger and slightly more caudal (100-600 km caudal to the Pr) than that of the injection No. 27.
The area of termination (Fig. 2B) was quite similar to that in case No. 27.

TTE.S: Experiment No. 60 is illustrated in Figure 10.

The small injection site had a dense core surrounded by several densely labelled cells which covered the outer-rostral restricted portion of the pPBel (Figs. lB, 10A; extent: 250600 pm caudal to the Pr).
The area of termination, in the amygdaloid complex, primarily occupied the ipsilateral CeL (Fig. 10B).
In this area we found a very high density of labelled terminals restricted to the lateral half of the CeL (Fig. 10Bl-B4).
This dense projection extended ventrally into a small adjacent portion of the caudal CeLC (Fig. 10Bl-B4).
Rostrally this labelling had a lower density (Fig. 10B5).
This intense labelling in the CeL strongly contrasted with the almost complete absence of labellingin the other subregions of the Ce and the other amygdaloid nuclei.
In the contralateral amygdala only a few labelled terminals were observed, symmetrically to the ipsilateral side, in the CeL and CeLC.

Results.S: Thus, these experiments showed that the rostral pPBcl and the outer portion of the pPBel projected, in the amygdala, primarily onto the CeL subregion.
In addition, experiment No. 60 showed that the pPBel contained neurons which projected to the CeLC.
It must be noticed that the injection site No. 60 was very close to the site No. 31 (see next section) which projected almost exclusively to the CeLC.
Experiments exhibiting a high density of labelling in the CeLC
In Figure 4D, ten experiments with injection sites located in the pPB exhibited, in the Ce, an area of intense labelling of terminals, located mainly or only in the CeLC subdivision.
The injection sites (Fig. 4D) covered all of the pPBd1, the inner-rostral, and the caudal portion of the pPBel and the pPBem.

Among these injection sites, two subgroups could be distinguished according to their location in the pPB area: The external subgroup (Fig. 4D) included experiments No. 31,3, 1,24,54, and 26 which contained injection sites located in the pPBel and the pPBem.

The dorsal superficial subgroup (Fig. 4D) included experiments No. 66,45,55, and 50 which had their injection sites located in the dorsal superficial portion of the pPB1: the pPBdl and the dorsal-caudal portion of the pPBel.
It must be noticed that the external subgroup and the superficial subgroups corresponded to two separate areas of the pPB, each of them projecting onto the whole CeLC.
The external subgroup.

TTE.S: The corresponding injection sites (No. 31, 3, 1,24, 54, and 26) were located in the pPBel and the pPBem (Fig. 4D).
The common feature of all these experiments was the dense or extremely dense labelling observed primarily and often exclusively into the CeLC.

These experiments were described from cmes No. 31 (described in detail) and 3, in which anterograde labelling primarily occupied the caudal CeLC, via the transitional cases No. 1 and 24, to the cases No. 54 (described in detail) and 26, in which labelling occupied the rostral CeLC.
Experiment No. 31 is illustrated in Figure 11.
The small injection site had a very small dense core surrounded by several densely labelled cells, in the inner portion of the pPBel (Fig. 11A; extent 200-400 pm caudal to the Pr).
The area of termination, in the amygdaloid complex, was primarily located in the ipsilateral CeLC (Figs.

As shown in Figure llBl-B4 a very high density of labelled terminals occupied a large caudal portion of the CeLC, up to the more rostral portion where the density of labelled terminals was lower (Fig. llB5).
The intense labelling in the CeLC strongly contrasted with the few labelled terminals found in the other subregions of the Ce: the CeL and the CeM (Fig. 11Bl-B5).
Only the portion of CeL and CeM adjacent to the rostral CeLC contained some densely labelled clusters.
Continuing with the labelling of the ce, a low density of labelled terminals was found in an indefinite area which ran from the CeLC rostrally (Fig. llB6).
Only sparse labelled terminals were observed in the SStr and the SIdiGPv (Fig. llB5,B6).
In the amygdala, outside the Ce, a small but dense cluster of labelled terminals was found in the rostral portion of the dorsolateral subdivision of the lateral amygdaloid nucleus.

In the contralateral amygdala a medium to high density of labelling was found in the rostral CeLC (corresponding to the levels 4 and 5 in Fig. 11B), whereas a low density of labelled terminals was found in the caudal CeLC.

Results.S: Thus in this case, although the labelling was less dense than on the ipsilateral side, there were fewer differences between the two sides than in all the previously described experiments.

TTE.S: Experiment No. 3 had a very small injection site located in the medial-inner portion of the pPBel (Fig. 4D), which projected, as did the site No. 31, to the caudal portion of the ipsilateral CeLC.
Experiments No. 1 and 24 had injection sites which overlapped the pPBel and pPBem, the former with a relatively large caudal extent and the latter with a rather rostral position (Fig. 4D).
The labelling primarily covered the whole ipsilateral CeLC.
In the contralateral amygdala, a labelling almost as dense as the one on the ipsilateral side occupied the rostral portion of the CeLC.
Experiment No. 54 is illustrated in Figure 12.
The injection site had a dense core surrounded by numerous and densely labelled cells, in the rostral portion of the pPBem.
This injection site was restricted in the coronal plane (Fig. 12A; diameter <300 pm), but its rostrocaudal extent was larger: 50 pm rostral to 400 pm caudal to the Pr.
As in previous cases of this section the area of termination, on the ipsilateral side, was primarily located in the CeLC (Fig. 12B).
But differing from case No. 31 (see Fig.
ZC), the most densely labelled area was almost exclusively located in the rostral half of the CeLC, as demonstrated by the photomicrograph in Figure 3B and the Figure 12B4,B5.
This labelling of very high density was rostrally continued by two clusters of dense labelling (Fig. 12B6).
Differing also from the previous cases the labelling was bilateral without an ipsilateral predominance.

Thus the most rostral portions of the contralateral CeLC (corresponding to levels 5 and 6 in Fig. 12) also contained a very high density of labelling, whereas in its other portions the labelling had a low density (level 4) or was completely absent (caudal levels 1-3).
On both side a medium to low density of labelled terminals was also observed in the SIdiGPv, the SStr (Fig. 12B6), the rostral portion of the ACo, and the cortex-amygdala transition zone ( C d ) .

Experiment No. 26 had a small injection site located in the most caudal portion of the pPBel and pPBem (Fig. 4D) which primarily and bilaterally projected, as did site No. 54, to the more rostral portion of the CeLC (levels 4-6).

Results.S: The dorsal superficial subgroup.

TTE.S: The corresponding injection sites (Fig. 4D) were located in the main pPBdl (NO. 66 and 45) and the external pPBdl (No. 55 and 50).
As in the external subgroup, the common feature of these experiments was the dense labelling primarily and often quite exclusively observed in the CeLC.

Results.S: These experiments were described from cases No. 66 (described in detail) and 45 which primarily projected to the caudal CeLC, via the transitional cases No. 55, to the case No. 50 which primarily projected to the rostral CeLC.

TTE.S: Experiment No. 66 is illustrated in Figure 13.
The injection site had a small dense core in the dorsal and caudal portion of the main pPBdl (Fig. 13A1) and the labelled cells extended ventrally to the dense core in the pPBdl.
The labelled cells were mostly restricted to this thin lamina (about 100 wn thickness) but had a relatively l a w extent direction (Fig. 13A; extent: 0-700 pm in the rostrocaudal caudal to the Pr).
The area of termination, primarily in the ipsilateral CeLC (Fig. 13B) was almost similar to that in case No. 31 (external subgroup).
The high density of labelling mainly occupied the caudal portion of the CeLC (Fig. 13Bl-B3).
Some clusters of lower density in labelling were also found in the other portions of the CeLC (Fig. 13B4,B5).

Continuous with the labelling of the Ce, a low to medium density of labelled terminals was found in an indefinite area (see Discussion) which prolonged the CeLC rostrally (Fig. 13B61, into the SStr and the SId/GPv (Fig. 13B5,B6).
Some labelled terminals were also observed in the Me and the ACo.

Results.S: In the contralateral amygdala the labelled terminals were almost absent.

TTE.S: The site No. 45 located in the main pPBdl(Fig. 4D) projected primarily as did the sites No. 66, to the caudal portion of the ipsilateral CeLC.

Results.S: Experiments No. 55 and 50 had very superficial injection sites located lateral and very lateral, respectively, to both the injections No. 45 and 66 (Fig. 4D).
The site No. 55 primarily projected to the intermediate portion of the CeLC (levels 3 and 4), whereas the site No. 50 exclusively projected to the more rostral portion of the CeLC (levels 4-6).
In the contralateral amygdala, low and medium density of labelling was observed rostrally in the CeLC, in cases No. 55 and 50, respectively.
Thus, these experiments showed that the pPBdl, the caudal and the rostral-inner portion of the pPBel and the PBem projected, in the Ce, primarily if not exclusively, to the CeLC subregion.
The anterograde labelling observed in the Cewas always more dense than that observed, in the same animal, in other regions also receiving a strong projection from the pPB.
Such a conclusion was drawn by analyzing each of the 43 experiments where the injection was located in the pPB area.

In these latter experiments, the density of labelled terminals was always higher in one subdivision of the Ce than in other regions, outside the amygdala of the same animal, but also exhibiting a high density of labelling.

Of course, in a few cases where the injection site was very small (less than 200 Kmj, the density of labelled terminals in the Ce was low but in these cases the labelling in the other regions was absent or lower than in the Ce.
Likewise, in some other cases where the density of labelling in other regions of the brain was very high, the density of labelling in the Ce was still higher.

Although the aim of the study was not to describe the extraamygdaloid sites of projection of the pPB area, it is interesting to briefly present them in order to permit a better understanding of this complex region.
These main projections, as numerous other, will be described in detail in following papers.
These main sites of projection were the substantia innominata, the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, the thalamus, the hypothalamus, and the region of the ambiguous nucleus.
The main labelling in the substantia innominata was ipsilateral in its dorsal portion, arising, in the pPB, mainly from the sites displayed in Figure 4A,B,D.
The main labelling in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis was ipsilateral, in its most lateral portion, arising, in the pPB, mainly from sites presented in Figure 4A, B, C.

The main labelling in the thalamus was bilateral and median, and included the gustatory thalamus, the rhomboid, the reuniens, and a portion of the submedius nuclei, arising, in the pPB, mainly from the sites shown in Figure 4A,B, D.

The main labelling in the hypothalamus was ipsilateral in the lateral caudal hypothalmus and median or bilateral in the median and medial preoptic nucleus, arising, in the pPB, mainly from the sites displayed in Figure 4C.
The main labelling in the region of ambigous nucleus was ipsilateral, originating mainly in site No. 54.
The control experiments

TTE.S: The twenty control experiments can be divided into three groups: The first group included 11 experiments with injection sites caudal to the PPB (in or near the superior vestibular nucleus) with (n = 6) or without (n = 5) spread into the most caudal portion of the pPB.
The main labelling was found in the cerebellum, vestibullar nuclei, and related regions (oculomotor nuclei, red nucleus, and thalamus).
Experiments with injection sites that did not spread into the pPB did not exhibit any labelling in the amygdala.
Experiments with spread into the pPB caudal portion (a few hundred km) exhibited only a few labelled terminals in the Ce.

In two cases, where the spread of the injection site clearly extended 200-300 pm in the dorsal and external portion of the more caudal portion of the pPBI, a few clusters of fibre labelling were observed in the CeLC.
The second group included two experiments with injection sites ventral to the pPBm and the pPBem.
In one case no labelling was observed in the amygdala.

In the other case where the injection site was below the caudal portion of the pPBem with a small spread into this latter area, a few clusters of fibre labelling were observed in the contralateral CeLC and only a few labelled fibres were observed in the ipsilateral CeLC.
The third group included seven experiments with an injection site rostral to the pPB, in the mesencephalic PB area (mPB).

In four cases where the injection site was weakly spread into the pPB area (200-300 km), a low to medium density of labelled terminals was observed in one subregion of the Ce according to the description of the projection of the pPB area onto the Ce made in the previous sections.
In the three other experiments without spread into the pPB area no projection was observed to the Ce.

It must be pointed out that in most of these seven experiments a high to very high density of labelled terminals was found in the medial nucleus of the amygdala and in the hypothalamus (primarily in the ventromedial and retochiasmatic nuclei).

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

The present results showed that in the amygdaloid complex: i) the pPB area projected primarily onto the ipsilateral side in the Ce nucleus, and to a lesser extent onto the BMA, BLP, and ACo nuclei of the amygdala and to the SId/GPv, SStr, and FStr regions which extend the amygdala rostrally, and ii) the projections of the pPB area to these latter regions were topographically organized.
This organization, suggested by the grouping of injection sites in Figure 4 is summarized in Figure 14.

This diagram, which interprets the results of the present study, shows that three compartments of connectivity can be recognized: 1) the region of the pPB filled in grey (Fig. 14A, including the pPBm, the pPBwa, the neurons in and medial to the brachium conjunctivum, and a thin lamina of neurons in the rostral pPBvl) projects very densely to the CeM (Fig. 14Bl-B5, grey region) and densely to the BMA, BLP, and ACo nuclei of the amygdala (Fig. 14B0, B2-R5, light grey region) and to the SIdlGPv, SStr, and FStr rostral regions (Fig. 14B4-B6, light grey region); 2) the region of the pPB filled with dots (Fig. 14A, including the pPBcl, an adjacent portion of the pPBvl and the outer portion of the pPBel) projects very densely to the CeL (Fig. 14B1-B4, region filled with dots); and 3) the hatched region of the pPB (Fig. 14A, including the pPBdl, a thin dorsal portion of the pPBcl, the more caudal portion of the pPBv1, all of the remaining pPBel and the pPBem) projects VerY densely onto the CeLC (Fig. 14B1-B5, hatched region) and densely in the region which continues the CeLC rostrallY and in the SIdiGPv, SStr, and FStr rostral regions (Fig.
14B5,B6, hatched region).

In addition (this is not illustrated in Fig. 141, it must be emphasized, that differing from other amygdaloid areas of termination, the dense projection onto the rostral portion of the CeLC is bilateral without an ipsilateral predominance.
Figure 14 shows a schematic division into three regions.
However, this description will need to be further investigated since it is probable that there exists other subregions in this organization.

The ventral portion of the pPBm appears to project mainly onto the medial portion of the CeM, the portion of the pPBm adjacent to the bc onto the central portion of the CeM, and the pPBwa with the ventral portion of the pPBvl onto the lateral portion of the CeM adjacent to the CeL.
This analysis needs to be continued, taking into account the fact that the transition area between two regions in the pPB projected to the transition area of the two corresponding regions in the Ce.
Finally, the special organization of the hatched region must be described in further detail.

Thus, the pPB hatched region could be divided into two regions: the superficial region (the main and the external pPBdl and the outer-caudal pPBel) and the external region (the caudal and the inner-rostra1 portion of the pPBel and the pPBem).

Each of the two regions projected on the whole CeLC, but in each subregion one portion (the main pPBdl and the inner-rostra1 pPBel) projects onto the caudal portion of the ipsilateral CeLC, and the other portion (the external pPBdl, the caudal pPBel, and the pPBem) projects bilaterally onto the rostral portion of the CeLC.

In addition, from the comparative analysis of the density of projection of each injection site, it was possible to evaluate i) the rostrocaudal extent of the subregions in the pPB area and ii) the relative density of parabrachial neurons projecting to the Ce (pPB-Ce neurons).
The rostrocaudal extent of the pPB region projecting to the CeM was approximately 800 to 200 pm caudal to the Pr.

In this region the density of pPB-Ce neurons was probably at a maximum in and around the medial half of the brachium conjunctivum, whereas it seemed relatively low in the ventrolateral portion near the pPBem.
The rostrocaudal extent of the pPB region projecting to the CeL was approximately 600 to 0 pm caudal to the Pr.
The rostrocaudal extent of the pPB region projecting to the CeLC was approximately 800 to 100 pm caudal to the Pr.
Both the PBel and the PBem seemed to contain a high density of pPB-Ce neurons.
Nomenclature and subdivision of the regions
The nomenclature and main divisions of the PB area (see Fig. 14A) was adopted from the description of Fulwiler and Saper ('84).
The division in the pPB area (caudal to the coronal plane where the inferior colliculus merges with the pons) and in the mPB area (rostral to the latter plane) does not modify this nomenclature.

Nevertheless a small modification was adopted for the pPBem: in the present study the pPBem extends slightly more rostrally (up to 100 I-Lm behind the Prj than in the study of Fulwiler and Saper ('84).
This modification was adopted because the rostral pPBem was rather undefined and all of the pPBem as defined in the present study projected to the same subdivision of the Ce.
The following points of the nomenclature were adopted: i) The pPBdl often included two (or more) dorsal superficial islet of cells, well separated by a thin fibre fasciculus.

In the present study, the main pPBdl corresponded to the main group of cells which extended dorsally to the pPBvl (in the caudal portion of the pPB area) and to the pPBcl (in the rostralportion of the pPB area) (see Fig. 4D, sites No. 45 and 66).

The external pPBdl corresponded to the other group which surrounded the rostral portion of the pPBel dorsolaterally (see Fig. 4D2, site No. 55). ii) The pPBel was currently divided into an inner portion (adjacent to the bc) and an outer portion (in dorsal and lateral position, see Fig. 4D1, sites No. 55 and 50 and Fig. 4C2, site No. 60).
The nomenclature and division of the amygdala (see Fig. 14B) was for the main nuclei adopted from the atlas of Paxinos and Watson ('86).

For the Ce nucleus we adopted the main subdivision of McDonald ('82) and Cassel et al. ('861, i.e., the CeL, the CeLC, and the CeM, with the following adaptation: The CeL subdivision in the present study corresponds well to the lateral subdivision of the Ce (CL) described by Cassel et al. ('86).
As these authors, we included the intermediate subdivision (CI) described by McDonald ('82) in the CeL.
Nevertheless, the rostral extension of the CeL in this study was generally found a little less rostral than in the description of Cassel et al. ('86).

It must be emphasized that this circular region was generally easy to identify on Nissl-counterstained sections due to a thin "capsule" of fibres which surrounds most of this subdivision and also to the intense labelling of well grouped neurons in this area.
Thus, this subdivision was an important anatomical mark used in order to determine the topographic organization between the pPB and the Ce.
The CeM subdivision in the present study corresponds in general to the medial subdivision (CM) of McDonald ('82) and to the medial (CM) and ventral (CV) subdivisions of Cassel et al. ('86).

However, we have included a thin dorsal lamina in the CeM, which roughly corresponds to the dorsal portion of the lateral capsular subdivision (CLC) described by McDonald ('82); in fact, in the present study, this thin lamina surrounded dorsally, then laterally, the CeL (see Figs. 5Bl,B2, 6B3,B4, 14Bl-B4).
This minor change was adopted in the study because the labelling in the CeM always included this dorsal and lateral lamina.

This slight modification permitted a more simple description of the projections to the Ce and provided an objective delineation of the dorsal border of the CeM which was not clearly determined by the Nissl.
Indeed, the CeLC included a thin lamina of cells in the more caudal portion of the Ce (see Fig. 14B1).
In addition, at the rostral level the CeLC included the amygdalostriatal transition (AStr) area as described in the atlas of Paxinos and Watson ('86) (see also DeOlmos et al., '85).

This more noticeable modification in the delineation of the CeLC was adopted because the dense projection to the CeLC always included this region on the border to the more restricted CLC area previously described.

This slightly modified description of the Ce was of interest for two reasons: 1) it made possible a simple description of the Ce afferents and 2) it gave a direct anatomical description of afferent regions.

Additionally, it must be pointed out that the small anatomical subdivisions recognized on a Nissl-stained section are difficult to identify on a Nissl-counterstained section, containing a dense black stained projection.
The region dorsal and rostral to the Ce was named transition area between the dorsal portion of the substantia innominata and the ventral portion of the globus pallidus.
This SIdiGPv region included the ventral portion of the globus pallidus and the amygdalopallidal transition rostral to the Ce (Paxinos and Watson, '86).
Nevertheless, the delineation as well as the nomenclature of this area is indefinite and therefore a matter of discussion among authors.

Thus, this area also corresponds to a large part of the substantia innominata dorsalis (Grove, '88a); it includes a part of the cholinergic cells of the nucleus basalis of Meynert (Paxinos and Watson, '86; Grove, '88a) and it largely overlaps the sublenticular area (De Olmos et al., '85).
The validity and limits of the topical organization
The artefactual labelling, due to an uptake of PHA-L by fibres of passage, was described as absent or very low by Gerfen and Sawchenko ('84).
This observation was confirmed by the results of the present study.

Indeed, in some cases where a strongly labelled injection site was precisely centred in the bc, none or only a few labelled terminals were observed in the nuclei (red nucleus, ventrolateral, and ventromedial thalamic nuclei), which are the main targets of the fibres passing through the bc, and arising from the deep cerebellar nuclei (Fad and Carman, '78; Haroian et al., '81).
Thus, it appears that such a phenomenon cannot be misleading in the present study.

At the level of the amygdala, the identification of the labelled terminals with the PHA-L technique using the intensification with nickel was very reliable, and artefactual labelling does not appear to occur.

In addition, the identification of labelled terminals (very thin fibres with numerous ramifications and varicosities) as compared to fibres of passage (thicker fibres without ramifications and varicosity) was generally easy.
The comparison of the density of terminal labelling was also easily made.
In fact, the only difficulty was to compare the areas of termination in the Ce in different animals.

Such a comparison was made with the use of the following anatomical marks: the optic tract, the stria terminalis, the cornmissural stria terminalis, and the fibres delineating the basolateral and lateral group of the amygdala.
In addition, the counterstained section permitted us to clearly identify the CeL subnucleus, the basolateralilateral group, and the intercalated main nucleus.
Thus, despite the fact that the borders of the CeM and CeLC were often not very well defined, it was possible to compare the labelled areas in different experiments.

At the level of the PB area the injection sites were often restricted (diameter between 400-600 prn) or very restricted (diameter < 400 Fm) and the extent of the injection site can be reliably estimated as the area which contained densely stained labelled cells around a small dense core.

The comparison of several adjacent (with or without overlapping area) injection sites with their respective projections shows that this evaluation of the injection site permitted a determination of the extent with an error that probably does not exceed 100 pm.

With such precision it was possible to recognize, without ambiguity, three different regions in the pPB area, although it was not possible to decide with certainty the boundaries between the three regions in the pPB.

Thus, the limit and the extent of the three regions represented in Figure 14A were only an estimation made by a careful comparison of the 43 injection sites made in the pPB (a selection of 29 of them is presented in Fig. 4).
In fact, it appears that with this type of strategy the regions were more precisely determined at the level of the amygdala than at the pPl3 level.
It is probable that a retrograde study with very small injection sites in several portions of the Ce could add further precision on the location of the pPB-Ce neurons in the pPB area.

However, such an extensive investigation was not in the field of the present study, and with the numerous data in the literature where retrograde studies have been performed, it is possible to obtain a relatively precise view of the question.
Comparison with data in the literature on the rat

Our results are in good agreement with data in the literature on the rat which demonstrated, using an anterograde marker, a strong projection of the pontine parabrachial area on the nucleus centralis of the rat (Norgren, '76; Saper and Loewy '80; Bernard et al., '89; Moga et al., '90).

In more detail our results are in full agreement with the study by Norgren ('76) which demonstrated an intense projection in the ipsilateral Ce and the substantia innominata after injection of tritiated proline centred in the bracliium conjunctivum.
The present results are also in general agreement with the study of Saper and Loewy ('80) who used tritiated proline and leucine with injections in the lateral and medial parabrachial areas.

They found on the ipsilateral side, an intense projection in the Ce and the substantia innominata and a more sparse projection in the anterior, the medial, the basomedial, and the posterior basolateral amygdaloid nuclei.
Indeed, in the present study we show that the pPBm, the pPBwa, and the portion of the pPBvl project onto all these latter nuclei except for the medial amygdaloid nucleus.
However, the adjacent rnPB area densely projects onto this area.

Finally, the present results fully confirm both the studies of Bernard et al. ('89) and Moga et al. ('90) which demonstrated a strong projection to the ipsilateral amygdala restricted to the Ce after wheat germ-HRP injections restricted to the pPBel.
It is interesting to note that in both cases (see Fig. 11C in Moga et al., '90) the anterograde labelling was in the CeL and probably also in the CeLC, but not in the CeM.

Thus, the present study is in accordance with all previous studies in the rat, but it extends the previous results considerably by providing a detailed and more complete mapping of the projections of the pPB area onto the amygdala, showing separate projections to the CeM and CeL and finding out a new and separate projection onto the CeLC.

Our results are also in good agreement with data in the literature on the rat which demonstrate numerous retrogradely labelled neurons in the pPB after injection of HRP or wheat germ-HRP in the ipsilateral Ce (Ottersen and Ben-Ari, '78; Ottersen, '81; Voshart and Van der Kooy, '81; Fulwiler and Saper, '84; Ma and Peschanski, '88; Moga et al., '90).

However, the analysis of data in the literature could lead to the conclusion that there exists a discrepancy between our results and others; in the present study all the injection sites in the pPB gave rise to a substantial labelling in the Ce, whereas most of the previous studies with a retrograde strategy showed retrogradely labelled cells only in restricted portions of the pPB (more often in the pPBel).

In fact, an analysis of individual experiments in these latter studies shows that the injection site was generally restricted to a subregion of the Ce which corresponds well to the topographic projection demonstrated by the present study.
Thus, Ottersen ('81, case RX6) found numerous retrogradely labelled cells in the pPBm, the pPBem, the pPBwa, and the pPBel after an injection in the caudal CeM and CeLC.

After an injection restricted to the CeLC he found numerous labelled cells in the pPBem (case RT 307); in addition, after an injection outside the Ce in the medial amygdaloid nucleus (case RZ10) the labelled cells were located outside the pPB, that is, in the mPB.
Fulwiler and Saper ('84) found numerous labelled cells only in the pPBel and pYBvl after an injection based on the entire Ce centred in the caudal CeL (case R159).

In a more recent study (Moga et al., 'go), numerous labelled cells in the caudal pPBwa, the inner pPBel, and the mPB area from an injection covering both the Ce (spreading probably into the CeM and CeLC) and the medial nucleus.

This study also showed that an injection centred in the caudal CeL (and spreading probably into the CeLC) gives rise to a very dense labelling in the pPBel (outer-rostra1 and caudal portions) and the pPBwa.
Finally, it is interesting to observe (Fig. 1B in Ma and Peschanski, '88) that a large injection in the Ce labels numerous neurons in almost all the subnuclei of the pPB area.
The present results, as summarized in Figure 14, were compatible with all these data in the literature.

Nevertheless, the present results (experiments 45, 50, 55, and 66; see Figs. 4, 13) suggest that, in the pPB, a superficial group of neurons (in the pPBdl and the outercaudal portion of the pPBel) projects additionally onto the Ce (the CeLC).
Furthermore, two points must be noted: i) The CeL subnucleus corresponds to the centre of the Ce and so an injection centred in the Ce was primarily in the CeL.
Thus, it is not surprising that, in the literature (see above), the cases most frequently presented, which correspond to injections well centred in the Ce, show numerous labelled cells in the pPBel.

Indeed, the present results demonstrated that the pPBel project densely onto the CeL, the CeLC, and for neurons on the border to the brachium conjunctivum, probably to the portion adjacent to the CeM. iil The problem of the precise rostrocaudal distribution of pPB-Ce neurons was not covered in detail because neither in the present study nor in the previous studies has this aspect been systematically studied.
We can only conclude that the present study is compatible with the two cases presented by Moga et al.
('go), which showed a high density of pPB-Ce neurons in the caudal pPBwa and in the two thirds rostra1 of the pPBel.

Thus, despite a relative lack of precision at the pPB level, the present study gives a mapping of pPB projections to the amygdala which allows us to give a coherent interpretation of previous data in the literature.
In addition, it suggests that the number of pPB-Ce neurons is probably higher than has been described in the literature.
Comparison with data in the literature concerning other mammals

Our results are generally in agreement with the data obtained in the hamster, the rabbit, the cat, and the monkey (Nomura et al.; '79; Mehler, '80; Russchen, '82; Kapp et al., '89; Ma et al., '89; Berkley and Scofield, '90; Halsell, '92).
In all these other studies a strong projection from the pPB area to the Ce was described.
In most of them, after an injection of HRP or Weat germ-HRP in the Ce, numerous retrogradely labelled cells were found mostly in the pPBel.
These results could correspond to injections centred in an area corresponding to the CeL of the rat (see previous section).
Further analysis is difficult because the mapping of parabrachio-amygdaloid projections was not as detailed in these species as in the rat.

Nevertheless, it is interesting to note that our results are compatible with those found in the cat, in three experiments with injection sites in the Ce, and a detailed mapping of the pPB area (Nomura et al., '79; Ma et a]., '89).
Indeed, considering these studies together, it can be observed that numerous retrogradely labelled cells were found in most of the pPB area (pPBm, pPBem, pPBwa, pPBel, pPBvl, and probably pPBcl).
Functional implication of the topic organization
As discussed in the beginning of the Discussion, the projections from the pPB area to the Ce were divided into three separate pathways.
The analysis of anatomical, electrophysiological, and behavioral data in the literature suggest a specific functional implication for each one of the pathways.

Thus, three different basic functions can be suggested: The pPB-CeLC pathway (Fig. 14, regions filled with hatched lines) would primarily be implicated in the processing of nociceptive and cardio-respiratory messages.
The pPB-CeL pathway (Fig. 14, regions filled with black dots) would primarily be implicated in the processing of autonomic and visceral messages.
The pPB-CeM pathway (Fig. 14, regions filled with grey) would primarily be implicated in the processing of gustatory messages.
As compared to these rather organized pathways, the pPB-SId/GPv pathway, on the other hand, has a larger convergence of information from the pPB subnuclei.
Clearly, the parabrachial area is a very complex region which probably processes a variety of different information.
Thus, the proposed division is obviously schematic and the overlapping and/or the interrelation of functions between subgroups of neurons in the pPB and in the Ce area is very possible.
The pPB-CeLC pathway.
A recent electrophysiological
study (Bernard and Besson, '88, '90a) shows that numerous neurons located in the pPBel and pPBem and backfired from the Ce were exclusively driven by noxious stimuli.

Other recent electrophysiological investigations (Hayashi and Tabata, '90; Slugg and Light, '90) such as the study using a marker of neuronal activity (C-fosikrox-24) (Bullitt, '90; Herdegen et al., '90) confirmed that numerous PB neurons receive noxious input.

This is in agreement with the electrophysiological demonstration that numerous dorsal horn lamina I nociceptive specific neurons project to the PB nucleus (Hayashi and Tabata, '89; Hylden et al., '85, '86b; Light et al., '87; McMahon and Wall, '85).

The existence of nociceptive input in the PB area is also supported by several anatomical studies in the rat (Zemlan et al., '78; Cechetto et al., '85; Ma and Peschanski, '88; Bernard et al., '89; Hylden et al.. '891, the cat (Bjorkeland and Boivie, '84; Wiberg and Blomqvist, '84; Panneton and Burton, '85; Hylden et al., '86a; Blomqvist et al., '891, and the monkey (Mehler, '69; Kerr, '75; Wiberg et al., '87).

These studies show primarily that numerous neurons located in lamina I of the spinal and medullary dorsal horn, which receive nociceptive inputs (see references in Besson and Chaouch, '871, reach the lateral and external portion of the pPB area.

A detailed analysis of data in the literature shows that in the pPB i) several nociceptive pPB-Ce neurons were recorded, in the rat, in the pPBel and in the caudal pPBem (Bernard and Besson, '90a); ii) the spinoparabrachial terminal fibres are mainly located caudally in most of the pPBl and rostrally in the pPBdl and the dorsal portion of the pPBcl (Cechetto et al., '85; Blomqvist et al., '89).
These data were confirmed by personal results in the rat; iii) the trigeminoparabrachial terminal fibres were mainly located in the pPBel and pPBem (Cechetto et al., '85; Saxon and Hopkins, '90).

This indicates that the pPB region (Fig. 14A, filled with grey) which projects onto the CeLC receives a strong nociceptive input and plays probably an important role in the processing of nociceptive messages.

Furthermore, this conclusion is strongly supported by a recent study (Bernard et al., '90, '92) which demonstrates that a very high proportion of neurons located in the CeLC (which receives afferent projections from the present pPB region) strongly respond to noxious stimulation.
In addition to the spinal and trigeminal inputs, this pPB region also receives an important input from the nucleus of the solitary tract (NTS) (Norgren, '78).
The projections from the NTS to the pPB area were described in detail in the rat, in a recent study by Herbert et al. ('90).

This study shows that this pPB region receives some afferent projections from i) the ventrolateral NTS and the periambiguous nucleus, which primarily receive respiratory afferents (Herbert et al., '90; see also Ellenberger and Feldman, '90); ii) the medial NTS which receives visceral afferents (Torvik, '56; Contreras et al., '82; Kalia and Sullivan, '82; Norgren and Smith, '88; Altshuler et al., '89) and also lamina I afferent projections (Menetrey and Basbaum, '87; Men& trey and De Pommery, '91); and iii) the rostral NTS (for the pPBem) which receives gustatory as somesthetic intraoral afferent projections (Hamilton and Norgen, '84; see discussion in Herbert et al., '90).
It must be pointed out that the neurons recorded in the pPBem were not gustatory (Norgen and Pfaffmann, '75) but responded exclusively to intraoral noxious stimuli (Bernard and Besson, '90a).

The dorsal portion of the pPBl also receives a dense projection from the Al, A5 areas, the Gigantocellular reticular formation, and the ventrolateral medulla implicated in cardiovascular regulation (Byrum and Guyenet, '87; Guyenet and Young, '87; Haselton and Guyenet, '90; Woulff et al., '90).
The precise role of these latter afferents and the NTS, in this presumably nociceptive pPB region, is not clear.
It could be hypothetized that they bring nociceptive visceral and aversive autonomic (respiratory and cardiovascular) information into this "nociceptive" pPB area.

Thus, this analysis strongly suggests that the nociceptive spino(trigemin0)-ponto-amygdaloid pathway (Bernard and Besson, '88, '90a; Bernard et al., '89) relays in the region of the pPB (Fig. 14A, grey) which project to the CeLC.
Interestingly, at least three peptides, substance P (SP), neurotensin (NT), and calcitonin gene related peptide (CGRP), label this nociceptive pathway with relative specificity.
The superficial laminae of the spinal and medullary dorsal horn contain a high level of SP and CGRP (Ljungdahl et al., '78; Schwaber et al., '88; Skofitsch and Jacobowitz, '85).

The pPB region which projects to the CeLC contains both numerous SP and NT immunoreactive terminals and neurons immunoreactive to SP and/or NT andlor CGRP, some of them identified as projecting to the Ce (Milner et al., '84; Block and Hoffman, '87; Schwaber et al., '88; Yamano et al., '88a,b; Block et al., '89).

The CeLC also contains a high density of SP, CGRP, and NT terminals (Wray and Hoffman, '83; Kruger et al., '88; Yasui et al., '91) of which a large proportion arises from the pPB area (Yamano et al., '88a,b).
In the cat, Berkley and Scofield, ('90) have identified a parabrachial relay from the solitary nucleus to the amygdala but they failed to find an important relay from the spinal cord to the amygdala.
Such discrepancies could be due to the species difference between the rat and the cat.

However, from the results of the present study, it could be hypothetized that the amygdaloid injections in the former study was centred in the CeL and/or the CeM and thus revealed the solitaro-ponto-amygdaloid pathway but not the spino-ponto-amygdaloid pathway which deal with the CeLC.
The pPB-CeL pathway.
The afferent projections in the corresponding pPB region (Fig. 14A, regions filled with black dots) were not completely different from those in the nociceptive area.
This pPB region also receives afferents from the lamina I spinal neurons.

However, the density of projections appears to be considerably lower in this region (pPBcl) than in the previous region (pPBdl) (Cechetto et d., '85; Blomqvist et al., '89); these data were confirmed by personal results in the rat.

Accordingly, the amount of afferent projections from the lamina I trigeminal neurons seems lower in this regon (outer-rostra1 pPBel) than in the previous region (caudal pPBel and pPBem) (Cechetto et al., '85; Panneton and Burton, '85).
However, these data do not permit us to evaluate this projection definitely.

On the other hand, this region receives a strong afferent projection from the NTS: i) the pPBcl receives a strong projection from the medial NTS and the area postrema (Herbert et al., '90) and ii) the outer-rostra1 pPBel (see Fig. 10 in the present study) receives a strong projection from the shell portion of the area postrema (van der Kooy and Koda, '83; Shapiro and Miselis, '85; see Fig. 31 in Herbert et al., '90).

Furthermore, the difference between this region and the previous one was sustained by the electrophysiological studies of Bernard et al. ('90, '92) which show that the proportion of neurons activated by noxious, somesthetic stimuli was much lower in the CeL (which receives afferent projections from this pPB region) than in the CeLC (which receives afferent projections from the previous "nociceptive" pPB region).

This region could be considered as a transitional area between the previous nociceptive region (common processing of visceral information) and the gustatory region (common processing of chemosensitive information).
ThepPB-CeMpathway.
The afferent projections in the corresponding pPB region (Fig. 14, regions filled with grey) were in fact different from the two previous regions.
Thus, this pPB region does not receive afferents from the lamina I spinal neurons (Cechetto et al., '85; Panneton and Burton, '85; Blomqvist et al., '89).

In the same way, despite some afferent projections from the trigeminal nucleus (interpolar subnucleus and paratrigeminal and/or the promontorium) in the caudal pPBm and the pPBvl on the border of the bc, it does not receive afferents from the lamina I trigeminal neurons (Cechetto et al., '85; Panneton and Burton, '85; Blomqvist et al., '89).

In fact, the main afferent projections of the gustatory portion of the pPB area arise from the rostral portion of the NTS (Norgren, '78; Herbert et al., '90) which receives gustatory afferent messages (Hamilton and Norgen, '84).
The gustatory portion of the pPB area is usually associated with the whole pPBm, the pPBwa, and an adjacent portion in the pPB1.
However, Herbert et al. ('90) found that the gustatory NTS projects to a more restricted area.

In fact, electrophysiological studies show that neurons responding to gustatory stimuli are located in a region which extends over an intermediate range that is in between these two estimates (Norgren and Pfaffmann, '75; Ogawa et al., '87).
In the present study, the region of pPB which projects to the CeM corresponds well to the gustatory region.
It is interesting to point out that the regions which received the highest density of rostral NTS afferents (Herbert et al., '90) also showed dense projections to the CeM (the present study).
Thus, this third pPB region relays gustatory messages from the rostral NTS to the CeM acd some other amygdaloid nuclei (basomedial anterior, corticoamygdaloid, and basolateral posterior).

It is interesting to point out that the pPBem which is included in the nociceptive pPB region could be considered as an area of transition with the gustatory pPB region because it processes intraoral nociceptive information (Norgren and Pfaff'mann, '75; Bernard and Besson, '90a).
The pP3-SIdlGPu pathway.
The present results show that all the pPBwa, the pPBm, the pPBem, the pPBel, and the pPBdl subnuclei projected substantially onto the SId/ GPv (Fig. 14).
In fact, all the pPB subnuclei send at least some projections onto this area.
In addition, the control injections show that the mPR also substantially projected onto the SIdiGPv.
These results are in good agreement with the recent study by Moga et al. ('90) which emphasizes the heavy input to the substantia innominata from the PB area.

In addition to the parabrachial input, the SId/GYv receives numerous afferent projections from the Ce itself, from the thalamus, the zona incerta, and the mesencephalic reticular formation (Grove, '88a).
Thus, the SIdiGPv is the centre of a large convergence of gustatory, visceral, and somesthetic information in which the pPB-SIdiGPv pathway has an important role.

Since the SIdiGPv includes part of the nucleus basalis of Meynert known for its cholinergic projections toward several areas of the cortex and its role in memory (Everitt et al., '87; Grove, '88a,b; see also references in Koliatsos et al., '90 and Wainer and Mesulam, '901, it could be hypothetized that the pPB-SIdiGPv pathway is implicated in the memorization of events in relation to gustatory, visceral, or nociceptive sensations.
Interestingly, a very high proportion of neurons strongly and specifically activated by noxious stimuli were recorded in the SId/GPv (Bernard et al., '90, '92).
